dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So Italy is banning American tourists this summer, right? That's a huge move.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So Italy is banning American tourists this summer, right? That's a huge move.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's specifically for travelers from the United States, according to the EU's recommendation to keep external borders closed until at least June 15th.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's specifically for travelers from the United States, according to the E U's recommendation to keep external borders closed until at least June fifteenth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The announcement did not specify whether the measure only applies to travelers from the European Union, since the EU recommends external borders remain closed to foreign nationals until at least June 15. The Italian Embassy in Washington D.C. did not immediately respond to questions from Forbes asking whether Americans or tourists from outside the EU will be allowed to travel to Italy on June 3.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, the Italian Embassy in Washington D.C. said Americans can actually travel there starting July 3rd. That's a bit confusing, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, the Italian Embassy in Washington D.C. said Americans can actually travel there starting July third. That's a bit confusing, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Italian Embassy in Washington D.C. did not immediately respond to questions from Forbes asking whether Americans or tourists from outside the EU will be allowed to travel to Italy on June 3.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. I mean, the U.S. State Department is still telling people to avoid all international travel, so there's definitely mixed messaging happening here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. I mean, the U.S. State Department is still telling people to avoid all international travel, so there's definitely mixed messaging happening here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S. State Department still advises citizens to avoid all international travel.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Italy itself is tightening internal travel too—Italians can't even move between regions now, which is a step back from their March rules.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Italy itself is tightening internal travel too-Italians can't even move between regions now, which is a step back from their March rules.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The decree also permits Italians to travel within the country, easing lockdown measures from March that prevented residents from moving outside their region.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and with 6,000 new COVID cases daily, compared to just 1,000 at the peak in March, it makes sense they're being cautious.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and with six thousand new COVID cases daily, compared to just ten hundred at the peak in March, it makes sense they're being cautious.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: only 1,000 new COVID-19 cases are being reported daily, compared to 6,000 at the peak of the outbreak in March, according to the Washington Post.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then you've got bars, restaurants, hairdressers—all that stuff still closed, while other businesses reopen June 3rd if they follow guidelines.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you've got bars, restaurants, hairdressers-all that stuff still closed, while other businesses reopen June third if they follow guidelines.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bars, restaurants, shops, hairdressers and religious services will be able to open on Monday, while all other economic activity will be allowed to resume on June 3, provided businesses follow social distancing and disinfecting guidelines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild, because tourism makes up zero percent of Italy's GDP? Wait, did I read that right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, because tourism makes up zero percent of Italy's G D P? Wait, did I read that right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats how much the tourist industry makes up of Italys total gross domestic product.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that number seems off—I think it might be a misstatement, 'cause tourism is huge for Italy. Maybe it's a placeholder or error?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that number seems off-I think it might be a misstatement, 'cause tourism is huge for Italy. Maybe it's a placeholder or error?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Probably. But still, the EU is really struggling with coordination—Germany closing borders with France and others, the Baltics not reopening to each other…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Probably. But still, the E U is really struggling with coordination-Germany closing borders with France and others, the Baltics not reopening to each other...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Germany, for example, opening its borders with France, Austria and Switzerland on June 15, creating a sort of travel bubble for the summer months. The Baltic countries of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania too are reopening borders to one another.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like every country is just doing its own thing, and tourists are caught in the middle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like every country is just doing its own thing, and tourists are caught in the middle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Summer 2020 is basically canceled for a lot of travelers, especially Americans trying to go to Europe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Summer twenty twenty is basically canceled for a lot of travelers, especially Americans trying to go to Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And with cases still so high in Italy, you gotta wonder if July 3rd will even hold.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And with cases still so high in Italy, you gotta wonder if July third will even hold.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Italy experienced one of the earliest and most severe outbreaks in Europe, but the country has made progress in recent weeks: only 1,000 new COVID-19 cases are being reported daily, compared to 6,000 at the peak of the outbreak in March, according to the Washington Post.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For real. I wouldn't be booking any flights just yet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For real. I wouldn't be booking any flights just yet.

artist_script:
HostA: So Italy is banning American tourists this summer, right? That's a huge move.
HostB: Yeah, and it's specifically for travelers from the United States, according to the EU's recommendation to keep external borders closed until at least June 15th.
HostA: But wait, the Italian Embassy in Washington D.C. said Americans can actually travel there starting July 3rd. That’s a bit confusing, isn't it?
HostB: It really is. I mean, the U.S. State Department is still telling people to avoid all international travel, so there’s definitely mixed messaging happening here.
HostA: And Italy itself is tightening internal travel too—Italians can't even move between regions now, which is a step back from their March rules.
HostB: Right, and with 6,000 new COVID cases daily, compared to just 1,000 at the peak in March, it makes sense they're being cautious.
HostA: But then you've got bars, restaurants, hairdressers—all that stuff still closed, while other businesses reopen June 3rd if they follow guidelines.
HostB: Which is wild, because tourism makes up zero percent of Italy's GDP? Wait, did I read that right?
HostA: Yeah, that number seems off—I think it might be a misstatement, 'cause tourism is huge for Italy. Maybe it's a placeholder or error?
HostB: Probably. But still, the EU is really struggling with coordination—Germany closing borders with France and others, the Baltics not reopening to each other…
HostA: It feels like every country is just doing its own thing, and tourists are caught in the middle.
HostB: Absolutely. Summer 2020 is basically canceled for a lot of travelers, especially Americans trying to go to Europe.
HostA: And with cases still so high in Italy, you gotta wonder if July 3rd will even hold.
HostB: For real. I wouldn't be booking any flights just yet.
